title: Winter pelage colour in snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus) from the Pacific Northwest
abstract: Winter pelage colour was assessed in 207 museum study skins from California, Oregon, Washington, and southwestern British Columbia. Specimens were classified into two distinct colour morphs: brown or white. The brown morph inhabits the coastal lowlands and the Olympic Mountains; the white morph occupies the Sierra Nevada, Blue Mountains, northeastern Washington, and the interior of British Columbia. Except for the occurrences of the brown morph above the snow line in the Olympic Mountains, this distribution correlates with the presence or absence of continuous snow cover and reflects selection for cryptic colouration. The absence of the white morph from areas in the Olympics with snow cover may be the result of intense selection for brown hares in adjacent lowland areas coupled with gene How or historical biogeographic factors in the Pacific Northwest. Both morphs occur in the Cascade Mountains and coexist at some localities. However, data are insufficient to evaluate the ecological distribution of brown and white hares in the Cascades.

abstract.text: Winter pelage colour was assessed in 207 museum study skins from California, Oregon, Washington, and southwestern British Columbia. Specimens were classified into two distinct colour morphs: brown or white. The brown morph inhabits the coastal lowlands and the Olympic Mountains; the white morph occupies the Sierra Nevada, Blue Mountains, northeastern Washington, and the interior of British Columbia. Except for the occurrences of the brown morph above the snow line in the Olympic Mountains, this distribution correlates with the presence or absence of continuous snow cover and reflects selection for cryptic colouration. The absence of the white morph from areas in the Olympics with snow cover may be the result of intense selection for brown hares in adjacent lowland areas coupled with gene How or historical biogeographic factors in the Pacific Northwest. Both morphs occur in the Cascade Mountains and coexist at some localities. However, data are insufficient to evaluate the ecological distribution of brown and white hares in the Cascades.

body_text.section: Materials and methods of a new white coat.

body_text.text: Locality data (Appendix 1) are from specimen labels. I obtained latitudes and longitudes for collecting sites from gazeteers or topographic maps in the Map Library at the University of Toronto. Coordinates could not be calculated from some collecting sites because of either insufficient data (e.g., locality consisted of only a County name) or place names that could not be found in gazeteers or maps. 'These localities were denoted as "no other data" or "not located precisely." Elevation is given only if it appeared on the specimen label.
body_text.section: Materials and methods of a new white coat.

body_text.text: General trends of snow depth for Oregon, Washington, British Columbia, and California were obtained from Sternes (1960) , Phillips (1965) , Potter (1965), and Dale (1966) . Data for specific weather stations in Oregon and Washington were from monthly summaries of climatological data published by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Environmental Data, and Information Service, National Climatic Center, Asheville, North Carolina.
body_text.section: Materials and methods of a new white coat.

body_text.text: Colour plates illustrating the two colour morphs are given in Nagorsen ( 1982) .

Brown morph Winter skins classified as brown had a brown dorsal pelage that was an agouti pattern with banded guard and fibre hairs. Some white or brownish white was apparent on the pinnae and hind feet and a small white patch of fur occurred on the forehead of some individuals. These white markings were also evident in skins with summer pelage. Ventral pelage was completely white and similar to summer pelage.

In a few specimens I observed isolated guard hairs that were either partly or completely white. Distribution of these white hairs varied but usually they occurred on the throat, neck, or shoulders. Similar white guard hairs were found on skins in summer pelage. Except for two specimens from British Columbia, no skins assigned to the brown morph were piebald or partly white in dorsal pelage.

Two snowshoe hares from British Columbia had unique winter pelages. One specimen (UBC 6029) was taken at Alta Lake, on December 23; the other (UBC 6058) was collected at Huntingdon, on February 9. Both hares had a pale brown dorsum with a frosted rump area. The frosted effect resulted from numerous guard hairs with black distal tips, a subterminal band of white or light tan, and a basal band of dark brown. Some white also was present on the hind feet and ears. Neither skin showed evidence of moulting and I assigned them to the bro.wn morph. These specimens may be examples of the silver-gene mutation, a coat colour mutant found in several species of mammals (Searle 1968 ).

Winter skins classified as white were white in dorsal and ventral pelage with some black hairs on the pinnae and some brown hairs on the head region and hind feet (see Severaid 1945) . The white pelage resulted from white guard and fibre hairs. Lyman ( 1943) attributed the white colour in these hairs to the absence of melanin pigments. Hairs of the underfur were pigmented and varied from gray to brown. The degree of whiteness depended on the length and thickness of the guard hairs (Nelson 1909; Severaid 1945) . In some skins the white guard hairs failed to cover completely the pigmented underfur in the head region and parts of the dorsum producing a dirty white colour.

In addition to colour, the two morphs differed in the length and thickness of the dorsal pelage. Length of dorsal guard hairs was 30 to 40 mm in the white morph and 20 to 30 mm in the brown morph. The white morph also had a denser, dorsal pelage.

Brown winter specimens from British Columbia ( In Oregon and Washington (Fig. 1 , Appendix 1) the brown morph occurs in the Olympic Peninsula and coastal areas; east of the Cascade Mountains in northeastern Washington and the Blue Mountains L. americanus are white in winter. Both morphs inhabit the Cascade Mountains. The brown morph has been taken at two localities on the lower west slope (2 mi (1 mi = 1.609 krn) E of Skykomish, 8 mi WSW of Skykomish), three localities on or near the crest (near Reflection Lake, 4900 ft ( 1 ft = 0.305 m), Mt. Rainier National Park; 2800 ft on Mt. Hood; Crater Lake), and three localities on the lower east slopes (7 mi E of White Salmon, Davis Creek, Fort Klamath). The white morph has been collected at one locality on the lower west slope (2 mi E of Skykomish), one locality on the crest (2800 ft on Mt. Hood), and at nine localities from the east slopes of the Cascades. Brown and white individuals coexist at some localities in the Cascades. The two morphs occur near Skykomish, Washington; and at three localities in Oregon: Fort Klamath, 2800 ft on Mt. Hood, and Davis Creek. Brown and white hares were collected on identical dates at these localities. Because skulls of white and brown individuals were adult (according to the fusion of the occipital cranial sutures), variation in winter pelage colour at these localities cannot be attributed to age variation of specimens.
body_text.section: Distribution of the winter colour morphs

body_text.section: Distribution of the winter colour morphs

body_text.text: For personal use only. either have a pigmented winter pelage or lack the winter moult and retain their brown autumn pelage throughout winter. Studies in captive animals or large series of museum specimens collected in late summerand autumn are needed to verify the number of moults in L. americanus from the Pacific coast.
body_text.section: Distribution of the winter colour morphs

body_text.text: Nonetheless, evidence from other studies suggest that the winter moult may be absent in populations of L. americanus that are brown in winter. Mountain hares (Lepus timidus) from Scotland are white in winter and have three annual moults similar to those in L. americanus that turn white (Hewson 1958) . In contrast, the brown hare (Lepus capensis) from Scotland which is brown in winter has only spring and autumn moults (Hewson 1963) . Similarly only two moults (spring and autumn) are present in the eastern cottontail rabbit (Sylvilagus floridanus) of North America, a species that is brown in winter (Negus 1958). Observations by Salomonsen (1939 Salomonsen ( -1940 . 238) on the red grouse (Lagopus lagopus) of Scotland are also pertinent: ". . . the Red Grouse is the only Lagopus-form entirely lacking the white winter plumage. The autumn moult is complete and the autumn plumage is kept until the summer-moult begins in early spring." Other populations of L. lagopus and the rock ptarmigan (L. mutus) undergo winter moults to white plumage (Salomonsen 1939 (Salomonsen -1940 .
body_text.section: Distribution of the winter colour morphs

body_text.text: If the presence or absence of a winter moult is responsible for the two winter colours in L. umericanus, then it is apparent that this is determined genetically and not induced by climate. R. T. Orr (unpublished data) raised three L. americanus captured at Lake Tahoe, California (Fig. l) , in outdoor pens at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco. Although winter from the Klamath Mountains. All hares collected in winter from the Cascades and Sierra Nevada of California were white.
body_text.section: Distribution of the winter colour morphs

body_text.text: From macroscopic and histological studies of captive hares from New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, Lyman (1943) determined that L. americanus has three annual moults: a spring moult from white to brown, an autumn moult from brown to brown, and a winter moult from brown to white. The moults are initiated by changes in phot.operiod (Lyman 1943) but temperature probably modifies the precise timing of moults (Rust 1962; Watson 1963) . Snowshoe hares that are brown in winter temperatures average well above freezing at San Francisco (Dale 1966), these hares acquired a white pelage each winter in captivity. The study skin of one individual (CAS 230) that died in captivity February 13 is indistinguishable from specimens taken in midwinter at Lake Tahoe. Snowshoe hares from the Olympic Mountains of Washington provide additional evidence for the -genetic basis of winter coat colour. A series of snowshoe hares in the Puget Sound University collection that were taken in winter at about 1800m elevation in the Olympics are completely brown. Snow cover in the Olympics exists continuously in winter at elevations above 450-900 m (Phillips 1965) . Several mammals that acquire a white pelage in winter have populations that are brown or partly brown in regions with moderate winter climates and little snow. Such variation in winter colour usually has been attributed to selection for cryptic colouration. Hall (195 1) reported brown and white morphs in the North American weasels Mustela eminea, M. rzivalis, and M. frenata. Moreover, Hall (1951) found transition zones where brown and white individuals coexist. Similarly, white-tailed jack-Can. J. Zool. Downloaded from cdnsciencepub.com by UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN on 10/07/21 For personal use only. rabbits (Lepus townsendii) from the southern Great Plains of North America and L. timidus from Ireland, southern Norway, and Sweden are brown, partly brown, or gray in winter (Nelson 1909; Salomonsen 1939 Salomonsen -1940 Hansen and Bear 1963; Hewson 1977) . Both species are completely white in regions with colder winters and continuous snow cover.

Distribution of the two winter colours in L. americanus can be explained in part by selection for cryptic colouration in winter. Coastal lowlands of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia are characterized by mild winter temperatures and heavy winter precipitation mostly in the form of rain. Winter snowfall in this region is sporadic and persists for short periods of time. East of the Cascades and Coast Mountains in the interior of British Columbia, northeastern Washington, and the Blue Mountains of Washington and Oregon winters are colder with continuous snow cover (Sternes 1960; Phillips 1965; Potter 1965) . Similarly the altitudinal range inhabited by L. americanus in the Sierra Nevada of California has heavy snowfall (Dale 1966) . The existence of the brown morph above the snow line in the Olympic Mountains, however, contradicts the correlation between white pelage and snow cover. Intense selection for the brown morph in surrounding lowland areas and gene flow among populations at different elevations in the Olympics may have resulted in the loss of the alleles for the white morph in populations occupying the small area above the snow line in these mountains. Another possible explanation is that the brown morph evolved during the Pleistocene in the unglaciated region along the Pacific coast of the western United States where a maritime climate would have favoured selection for a brown pelage in winter (Dalquest 1948; Nagorsen 1982) . Populations of L. americanus that inhabit the Olympic Mountains could be derived from these coastal populations as a result of postglacial dispersion.

Brown and white hares inhabit the Cascade Mountains but the paucity of winter specimens, particularly from the west slopes, makes it impossible to map the precise distribution of the two morphs in this region. Although Nelson (1909) speculated that the two morphs inhabit different elevations near Fort Klamath in the southern Cascades of Oregon, altitudinal distribution of brown morph should be at a disadvantage at these sites. Other locality records for the brown morph in the Cascades are from lower elevations on the east and west slopes (2 mi E of Skykomish, 8 mi WSW of Skykomish. 7 mi E of White Salmon, Davis Creek, Fort Klamath), areas where there may be year-to-year variation in the depth and duration of snow cover.

Long-term research in the Cascades Mountains is needed to assess the ecological distribution of the two winter-colour morphs. Year-to-year variation in the ratio of brown and white hares at various localities on the east and west slopes of the Cascades would be essential data for interpreting colour variation in this region. The genetic basis for the two morphs, the extent of gene flow among populations, and spatial differences in the relative fitness of the morphs should also be determined (Endler 1977). back_matter.text: I thank the curators who allowed me to examine specimens in their collections: Luis Baptista (CAS), Hugh Genoways (CM), Charles Handley (USNM), Larry Heaney (UMMZ), Murray Johnson (UPS), Karl Koopman (AMNH), Edward Miller (BCPM), James Patton (MVZ), Robert Rausch (BMWSH), Maria Rutzmoser (MCZ), J. Mary Taylor (UBC), and B. J. Verts (OSUFW). I am particularly grateful to Murray Johnson for allowing me to examine his series of study skins from the Olympic Mountains and for sharing his knowledge on mammals of the Pacific Northwest. Robert Orr kindly provided information on his experiments on moults in captive snowshoe hares. I thank an anonymous reviewer for valuable suggestions and criticisms of the manuscript. This research was part of an M.Sc. thesis at the University of Toronto and was financed in part by NSERC grant A2385 to Randolph Peterson.

FIGREF0.text: Fig. 1, Appendix 1) are confined to the lower Fraser Valley. Except for one specimen, a series of skins from Alta Lake and Green Lake in the southern Coast Mountains are white. Snowshoe hares from Hope and Texas Creek in the Fraser Valley and from areas east of the Fraser River are white in winter.

FIGREF1.text: Distribution of the two winter colour morphs of L. americanus in the Pacific Northwest. Solid circles are localities where hares are brown, open circles are localities where hares are white, and partly shaded circles are localities where both morphs have been taken. Localities are described in Appendix 1. Stippling denotes arid regions not inhabited by L. americanus.
